title: Why are new champions not disabled in ranked for a week?
body: Seriously?!?  Why are new champions not disabled in ranked for a week?  New champions with new mechanics are nearly an automatic loss if your team picks them.  It was true with Yasuo, Azir, Gnar, and now Bard.  It is especially bad with new supports because players who aren't even used to supporting decide to use the champion.  I have now played two ranked games in a row where a player on my team locked in Bard support and then fed.

> nope, because support is the least important role

Sounds like something an arrogant marksman would say. Support is as important as any other role, or even more important. The support controls the map, keeps teammates alive, heals, shields, peels, CCs, initiates, disengages, and babies the marksman in lane by healing, shielding, poking, zoning, warding, and even helping with last hitting.

I barely play support and I hate supporting, but I still have respect for that role and I understand how important it is. The balance of any game can easily be tilted one way or the other by any role, including support.

In bronze, adc is the most important role because 90% of games are decided by which adc wants to facetank everything (jk its usually both). Everywhere else, a good support can win bot even if your adc is incompetent, and then more or less control the game with wards/engages (2 things soloqers tend to fuck up). Sure, you don't get to right click people to death, but as long as it isn't bronze I trust the soloqers to do that somewhat well once I get them fed.

I love supporting, it makes me feel like I'm helping everyone out without being an "important" target of the enemy team.
Playing as Bard, I felt like an actual support because I was walking around (addictive chime collecting too strong) but I felt like I was helping even though I wasn't in lane the whole time, and running around helping other lanes. I also wasn't really worried if I was going to take any kills, because I didn't have anything for offense, besides my Meeps and my Q.
His ultimate allowed me to help people get kills even when I was no where near, or if I was fully intending to just get more chimes.
I do agree with letting new champions be available in ranked after the first week, because no one wants to go against a new champion, since it's going to be a win for you (since no one knows how to fight the new champion) or a win for them (same reason, but could be because you don't know how to play as the new champ).
I was with a Kalista yesterday, which was my first time as Bard, and I had no clue if it was her first time as well, but we were actually doing good, despite me leaving once at a bad time, but I always left a health pack or two before I left.
30 assists... New record for me.

is learning a new champion THAT hard? jeez. just read what his abilities are and THINK about what you will do in lane. im not talking about think mid game. im talking about think and visualize what you will do WHILE LOADING.

if you come up with a plan for what to do in certain situations before the game even starts, you're so much more likely not to fuck up and lose.

i was good with azir on launch because i watched a shit ton of videos, and studied him very hard. the same went for yasuo, velkoz, and gnar. you don't even need to play a champion to be good at it. you just need to know how to PLAY.

Just to point out 2 things : 
*You* were good because you watched a lot of videos and "studied him very hard". I'm sure you're in the minority that puts that much effort.  

Most champion still need a few games to get really used on their beat and how they work. (Thinking Gnar's or Rumble's resource management and gauging skill use). It's not just about knowing how to play, it's about adapting to the beat of the champion. Maybe you can watch a lot of videos and get used to it really quickly in game. But not everyone can do that and not everyone will put the efforts to watch that many videos. I know after I've seen the same combo being done 20 times, I can't stand to watch much more even tought I could still learn more.

Honestly if Riot was more committed to public testing they should release a new champion to Normal games for an entire month before they will let them go live on Ranked.

Azir was just a train-wreck of bugs and glitches and then he became over powered due to them being fixed XD.

PBT is great and all but it has been proven time and time over that unless a champion gets tested on a world scale they do not find as many glitches as fast.

I still see them die while the support is warding and afk because the support ganked mid, theres no way the average soloqer is ready for something like "Ok there are a lot of chimes around mid let's shove so I can go grab them quick"

ok, now ask yourself, when do you have a higher chance to win 4 v 5, when your support dc at 1st or when any other role dc at 1st
k, i actually won 4v5 as support nidaree (very tanky nidalee) and as jungle soraka but... well, you see

If one of the solo laners is afk you're just boned. The team can somewhat survive losing any of the other 3, depending on the champs and the team comp. For example, if the support is afk and you've got Fiora, Vi, and Viktor, odds are your adc is getting zero peel so they might as well be afk anyway.

Thats why I avoid ranked like the plague when a new champion drops, at least for a few days.

I stick to normals where a loss doesn't mean much of anything.

I do agree that new champs should be banned from ranked for a week though (they do it for the LCS, so why not ranked play?)

I agree. Obviously playing a new champ, especially for the first 10 or so games, is bad for your team and lowers your win chance. Picking a champ that you don't know how to play is intentionally assisting the enemy team. Once champion mastery is live, that should be used to restrict which champs you can play in ranked. If you haven't played 10+ games and/or have a certain mastery level then you can't use the champ in ranked.
